From culture to cuisine and pampering to partying — you’ll find everything you need, want, and wish for in Downtown Melbourne. SHOP From boutiques and antiques to handcrafted skincare and specialty cigars, you can find them here. SHOP IN DTMB DINE With over 40 craft restaurants and bars, indulgence is expected in Downtown Melbourne. DINE IN DTMB PLAY Rent a kayak, take in live theater or rock out in one of many local music venues. Downtown Melbourne is a playground for all ages. PLAY IN DTMB EXPLORE Explore Downtown Melbourne’s pedestrian-friendly side by visiting its waterfront parks and vibrant wall murals. History and heritage What we do Careers Contact us Left nav - about us Executive leadership team Our Managing Director oversees six organisational portfolios with a broad range of responsiblities: Service Futures Service and Asset Lifecycle Service Delivery Customer, Community and External Affairs People and Transformation Corporate Services. Organisational Structure Click to enlarge image Executive leadership team ​Leadership team Title and responsibilities​ ​ ​ Dr Nerina Di Lorenzo Managing Director Dr Nerina Di Lorenzo was appointed Managing Director on 1 December 2021 , after having spent two years as Melbourne Water’s Executive General Manager of Service Delivery . She has had over 21 years of experience in senior leadership roles, including almost five years as CEO of Moreland City Council. Her roles have spanned the areas of Asset Management, Infrastructure Operations, Project Delivery and Business Improvement. Prior to this, she held roles in the oil industry working on the oil rigs in Bass Strait. Nerina has a Bachelor of Engineering, a Bachelor of Business and a PhD centering on the topic of organisational change management. Chris Brace Executive General Manager, Service Futures Chris Brace is responsible for the Service Futures portfolio, which holds the medium- to long-term planning horizon and how our business adapts to coming challenges. Service Futures encompasses enterprise strategy, evaluation, monitoring and reporting functions, as well as modelling and research. In addition, the portfolio manages the end-to-end delivery of urban planning functions, strategic goals and our approach to critical adaptation issues. ​ Craig Dixon Executive General Manager, Service and Asset Lifecycle Craig Dixon is responsible for the Services and Asset Lifecycle portfolio, including the medium-term planning horizon (1-5 years) and translating our strategies into programs and capital development plans. The portfolio holds both growth and renewals planning, and develops and delivers capital built and natural infrastructure programs and manages assets. Sue Jackman Executive General Manager, Service Delivery Sue Jackman is responsible for the Service Delivery portfolio, which holds the short-term planning horizon to support reliable provision of day-to-day services. This includes delivering our core operational services in water supply, sewerage, waterways, flooding, drainage and land management that are essential to our customers and community, as well as all maintenance, planning, scheduling and execution to support them. Vivien Allimonos Executive General Manager, Customer, Community and External Affairs Vivien Allimonos is responsible for the Customer, Community and External Affairs portfolio, which holds all public-facing activity including our whole-of-business communications, marketing and media functions. The portfolio also holds customer insights and experience as well as frontline customer service activities, public engagement, Traditional Owner relationships and internal communications. Paula Jeffs Executive General Manager, People and Transformation Paula Jeffs is responsible for the People and Transformation portfolio.  This portfolio works to provide the right workplace environment to support our people to do their best work. It includes Capability, People Experiences, Business Transformation, Organisational Effectiveness, Health and Safety, Environment and Quality, and People Services. Fiona Schutt Executive General Manager, Corporate Services Fiona Schutt is responsible for the Corporate Services portfolio, which manages key enablement systems and functions including finance, procurement, audit, risk and legal, and information technology services. Melbourne Main Street receives Three Awards at the 2023 Florida Main Street Secretary of State Awards - Downtown Melbourne Skip to content Home Events The Flavor Experience landing page Shop Dine Play Explore Parks Murals STAY LIVE WORK PLAN STAY LIVE WORK Directory & Map About Downtown Melbourne Melbourne Main Street Membership Leadership History News & Stories Membership Visitors Guide Contact MENU 74° Directory Events Search Home Events The Flavor Experience landing page Shop Dine Play Explore Parks Murals STAY LIVE WORK PLAN STAY LIVE WORK Directory & Map About Downtown Melbourne Melbourne Main Street Membership Leadership History News & Stories Membership Visitors Guide Contact MENU Events Directory Search × Search for: Close Home » Melbourne Main Street receives Three Awards a … Home » About » News & Stories » Melbourne Main Street receives Three Awards a … Melbourne Main Street receives Three Awards a … July 22, 2023 Melbourne Main Street is proud to have received three Secretary of State awards at the 38th Annual Preservation on Main Street conference Thursday, July 20, 2023. Secretary Cord Boyd presented the 2023 Florida Main Street Awards at the Reilly Arts Center in Ocala, FL. Secretary Boyd annually recognizes outstanding Main Street organizations for innovative projects, impactful people, organizations, and businesses throughout Florida’s 57 Main Street communities. Secretary Boyd states, “These awards highlight not only inventive projects and processes but also individuals who help distinguish their communities.” Melbourne Main Street and representatives earned the following awards: Local Leader of the Year, Board Member of the Year, and Telling Your Story. Like many non-profit organizations, Melbourne Main Street relies heavily on volunteers, board members, community leaders, and businesses to promote our district as a premiere destination. Two of the awards recognize individuals working tirelessly to improve Downtown Melbourne for residents, business owners, visitors, and the community. Local Leader of the Year – Paul Alfrey In every community, it takes a leader to move the community forward, to lead with strength and grace, and to have the ability to see all sides before making decisions. In Downtown Melbourne, that is Mayor Paul Alfrey. Mayor Alfrey is one of Downtown Melbourne’s biggest supporters. As a Melbourne native, he has a personal connection with the area and wants to see it reach its full potential. He is respectful of history while working to catapult it into the next generation. He is always at the forefront of advocacy for new developments and residential density while maintaining the unique balance we all desire. He doesn’t shy away from complex and difficult situations and always works to ensure a balanced approach to solutions. Melbourne Main Street began its partnership with Mayor Alfrey in 2021 during the pandemic. During the last year, he has been working in tandem with us, listening, guiding, solving complicated issues, supporting us with personal funds, volunteering, and advocating for the important work we do for our community. He is a leader who has a vision and understands how public policy, public safety, and city finances work. He keeps an open mind, ensures constitutional rights are protected, and makes good decisions for our community. Since taking office two years ago, Mayor Alfrey has had the most impact on his leadership as it relates to the homeless in our community. He has been a huge advocate for homeless issues in the area, allocating $2.5 million from American Rescue Funds from the city’s budget toward a new comprehensive facility. He works alongside city staff, Melbourne Main Street, Daily Bread, and local property owners to find compassionate solutions to solve this extremely complex situation. Mayor Alfrey clearly understands how vital economic development is to our community and downtown and embraces new ideas while understanding and educating himself. He works to negotiate and work with others to enable our community to thrive. Meeting with property owners, developers, and critical partners – all to find the best opportunities and projects for Downtown Melbourne. He regularly attends the Melbourne Main Street board and business owner meetings, listening and speaking on current issues in Downtown. He is a centerpiece at our annual Candlelight Shopping & Tree Lighting Ceremony as well as the Best Bite presenter at our annual Downtown Melbourne Food and Wine Festival. Mayor Alfrey is a huge proponent of Melbourne Main Street’s work to enhance our community by creating and enhancing our unique location. He is always present, keeps us informed and connected, and is willing to hear new ideas and keep things moving forward. Board Member of the Year – Corey Runte Melbourne Main Street nominates Mr. Corey Runte as Board Member of the Year for his outstanding service to our organization. Mr. Runte, whose office is in Downtown Melbourne, has been involved in Melbourne Main Street for more than 12 years in various capacities. He has executed the Four Points through his service on Economic Vitality, Promotions, Organization, and Design committees and consistently makes a positive impact on the organization. In the fall of 2020, facing the fallout of the pandemic and during a tumultuous time in the 0rganization’s history, Corey volunteered to take the critically important role of Board Chair when the organization and leadership were in crisis. Facing resignations from officers and other board members, he took the reins and got to work. He served for 2.5 years guiding our Board through a full organizational transformation and finished his term in December of 2022. He was instrumental in the restructuring of the Board of Directors, updating bylaws, recreating our chart of accounts, enhancing technology, and organizing the first-ever Board retreat. In 2022, he also tackled launching a complete rebranding and a new, comprehensive website. In addition, he led with determination and grace, while welcoming business and community leaders from a wide representation of our community who are committed to the revitalization of Downtown Melbourne. His infectious energy and vision are palatable. His steadfast vision for a better downtown was supported through thousands of hours dedicated to building relationships with the board and committee members, businesses, and property owners while enhancing relationships with members of the City Council and City staff. Since April of 2022, Mr. Runte personally raised more than $15,000 for our mission, which surpasses all other volunteers. During his unending devotion to our organization, he has never faltered. Even when welcoming twin boys, moving twice, running for reelection, and building a house! During the last year, we realized record revenue increases through events and private sector contributions, revitalized events with successful customer satisfaction, repaired relationships, and had more fun than we could capture. Corey has a special way about him as a person and a leader, strengthening relationships, our mission and reputation and never losing sight of our primary goal of revitalization. Melbourne Main Street and Downtown Melbourne would not be what it is today without him, and we are eternally grateful for his service and his continued impact. Corey Runte is incredibly deserving. Telling Your Story (Category B) Melbourne Main Street is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization committed to positioning Historic Downtown Melbourne as the center of the community and the preferred destination for authentic economic activity. The mission is to revitalize and enhance the economic growth of Historic Downtown Melbourne by strengthening and showcasing the community’s positive unique characteristics. After many years of a stale and outdated brand, the Melbourne Main Street Board of Directors invested in a rebranding of all assets to further propel the mission for the community and our organization. A brighter, more vibrant logo and a comprehensive website were a top priority and a considerable investment. With a strategic partnership from a local advertising and marketing company MTN Advertising, which also has a passion and desire for the improvement of Downtown Melbourne, the organization was able to produce a stunning new brand to propel the community forward. The beginning phases of the discussion circled around the name identity of the organization and the district. During the rebranding, the shift was made to identify this area as DTMB with Melbourne Main Street also included. The syllable-based acronym was developed for simplifying communication in digital conversations. When people talk about visiting our community and posting about their experiences, most refer to it as Downtown Melbourne, which we now term DTMB. This new clarity has helped better market the mission of Melbourne Main Street for revitalization. Downtown Melbourne and better connect to the community and visitors about our mission, allowing for a fun and memorable way to describe our area. The identity was crafted with bold block letters symbolizing timeless revitalization and economic growth, while the simplistic sail, crane, and wave carved within the negative space help preserve the unique characteristics of the Historic Downtown Melbourne waterfront location. This refreshing new logo is prominent up and down New Haven Avenue on signage and street poles and helps identify this quaint, yet vibrant community of DTMB. All new publications, marketing, and assets now showcase the DTMB logo which can be seen on billboards, the website, rack cards, the Visitor Guide, letterhead, folders, promotional materials, membership program brochure, and throughout the district. Get to know the Melbourne Main Street Board of Directors and committed team. MELBOURNE MAIN STREET BOARD OF DIRECTORS OFFICERS Cassandra Hartford BOARD CHAIR, 2024-PRESENT, DIRECTOR, 2021-PRESENT BIO Cassandra Hartford is a distinguished professional with years of experience in real estate and client relations. Currently, Cassandra occupies many roles that allow her to utilize her exceptional skill set to its fullest potential. As a Real Estate Advisor, Cassandra aims to be a beacon of knowledge and guidance for all of her clients. Cassandra specializes in a variety of asset classes; anything from residential real estate, to commercial real estate, investment portfolios, and development. She is well-known for her dedication and unwavering commitment to each individual. Over the years, Cassandra has developed an ever-expanding network and continues to build lasting relationships with many loyal clients. As a passionate professional, Cassandra takes pride in staying up-to-date with current market trends. Her natural interest in real estate and innate desire to help others can be directly attributed to her stellar reputation and track record. In her free time, Cassandra loves spending time with her family, tending to her Koi Fish, or catching a local music or comedy show. She also enjoys Improv Acting and giving back to her community. Mike Hill VICE-CHAIR 2025-PRESENT, DIRECTOR, 2024-PRESENT BIO Michael Hill is a small business owner, he and his wife co-manage Tuckaway Shores Resort in Indialantic, FL. He truly understands how important volunteering and community involvement is to the local community. That is evidenced by his active participation in local government and engagement in multiple organizations including Melbourne Main Street and the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce; organizations that promote and make a measurable impact to the local economy. His passion is contributing his time and efforts to the continued growth and revitalization of our local community, including historic downtown Melbourne. Michael’s career began in the United States Army where he served for over 20 years with distinction and retired in 2004. He held numerous positions during his career from an Airborne Artilleryman to the Director of Training Development where he was responsible for the daily operations and management of the US Army Recruiting School. During his career he was stationed at Ft. Bragg, NC, Vicenza, Italy, Ft. Jackson, SC, and multiple assignments with the US Army Recruiting Command in the Northeast. Upon retirement from the US Army, Michael held multiple positions with both non-profit and for-profit companies in sales and operations roles. In those organizations he held local, regional, and V-level roles providing him exceptional experience that he leveraged to grow those organizations. Michael loves spending time with his wife Pam, daughters Brandi and Kristi and his grandchildren Carolina and Caleb. He is very active and enjoys outdoor activities such as paddleboarding, biking, one-wheeling, downhill skiing, and paramotoring. Lory Milton TREASURER 2024-PRESENT, DIRECTOR, 2023-PRESENT BIO Lory Milton is the current Vice President, Commercial Loan Officer at Marine Bank and Trust. She works closely with many small–business owners in the region building relationships to help business owners achieve their dreams. Lory is a University of Central Florida graduate with a Bachelor’s in Criminal Justice, and a longtime resident of the Space Coast. Growing up in Melbourne, Lory has enjoyed watching and being a part of the Space Coast’s growth and is excited for what the future holds for Downtown Melbourne. Lory serves as PTO Vice President at her son’s school, is a Board Member of The Gift Angel Society, and enjoys volunteering with the Brevard Children’s Hunger Project. Jordan Williams SECRETARY 2024-PRESENT, DIRECTOR, 2023-PRESENT BIO Jordan Williams owns Downtown Divas in Downtown Melbourne as well as Tangled Rose, in Downtown Melbourne and Cocoa Village.  She has a special affinity for downtowns and will be bringing her fresh perspective and vision for social media marketing, content development, and event planning to the Board of Directors. Jordan is looking forward to marketing DTMB as a destination for shopping, playing, and exploring while making deeper connections with the other businesses in Downtown Melbourne. DIRECTORS Kat Butler DIRECTOR, 2024-PRESENT BIO Kat Butler, North American Properties David Cable DIRECTOR, 2020-PRESENT BIO David Cable is a multi-million dollar, full-service, realtor with RE/MAX Elite. Working with his team of trusted local business partners, he’s able to successfully fulfill his clients’ every need, from start to finish and beyond. In addition to supporting Brevard public schools,  he is involved in several charities that are largely focused on funding women, children and animals. He is also actively involved in the community as an Executive Board member of the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce and an active member of the Palm Bay Chamber of Commerce. David and his wife, Wendy, live beachside in Indialantic. Bernard (Bernie) Clevens DIRECTOR, 2025-PRESENT BIO Bernard S. Clevens is the Founder and Principal of Thematic Capital Group (“TCG”), a real estate investment firm in Melbourne, Florida. As of December 2024, the company manages approximately $28M in assets. The company focuses on value-add industrial real estate investments in the southeast. Raised in Melbourne, Florida, Mr. Clevens believes that Downtown Melbourne is well positioned to benefit from a great location, a storied history and charming downtown streets. He joined the Board to drive further economic growth to Downtown Melbourne. The TCG portfolio includes a property in Downtown Melbourne, so his firm has a direct interest in the success of the local business community. He and his wife are both from Brevard County and are proud to raise their two children in Melbourne. Mr. Clevens earned his bachelor’s degree from Bowdoin College and holds an MBA from Emory University’s Goizueta Business School. Matthew Flores DIRECTOR, 2024-PRESENT BIO Matthew Flores, BRPH Don Hemmenway DIRECTOR, 2024-PRESENT BIO Don Hemmenway retired as a Senior Engineering Manager from Renesas Electronics in Palm Bay (formerly Harris Semiconductor) after a 40-year career in microelectronics design and manufacturing.  He was awarded 25 US and European patents, published numerous technical papers, and directly contributed to the implementation of multiple generations of tactical and strategic national defense programs. Don and his wife, Cathy, raised four children in Brevard County and are extremely proud of their many accomplishments (including six grandchildren!).  In 2019 they moved to a permanent residence on Crane Creek in Downtown Melbourne. Since retirement in 2023, they enjoy daily walks down New Haven Avenue to the harbor, as well as partaking in the diverse dining, shopping, and entertainment opportunities downtown. Don is passionate about applying his time and talents to improve both Downtown Melbourne and his local Crane Creek Landing community.  He is particularly inspired by the rich history of Downtown Melbourne and would like to improve how that story is delivered to enhance the visitor experience. Corey Runte IMMEDIATE PAST CHAIR, 2023; DIRECTOR, 2019-PRESENT BIO Corey serves as Vice President at Certified General Contractors, Inc., located in Historic Downtown Melbourne, bringing a wealth of experience and a deep commitment to community to the Board. A resident of Melbourne Beach with his wife, Krista, and their three young sons, Corey actively engages in local initiatives. He serves as a member of the Economic Development Commission of the Space Coast and has previously chaired the boards of both Melbourne Main Street (MMS) and the City of Melbourne’s Historic & Architectural Review Board. His involvement in Main Street organizations spans over a decade, with a dedicated eight-year tenure at MMS. Corey is passionate about revitalizing Downtown Melbourne and offers the Board a unique and energetic perspective informed by his professional experience in construction and his long-standing commitment to community development. Toni McGovern DIRECTOR, 2025-PRESENT BIO Toni McGovern is the Director of Sales of Hotel Melby with an impressive 15-year tenure in the dynamic world of hospitality management. With a vibrant energy and an unwavering passion for creating memorable experiences, Toni has significantly increased Occupancy and Revenue at Hotel Melby since taking on her role in 2021. Having been enchanted by the charm of Melbourne since her first visit in the 2000s, she finally made Brevard County her home in 2016. This city, known for its vibrant arts scene and culinary delights, has captured her heart in a way that fuels her ambition: to position Downtown Melbourne as the ultimate destination for curious travelers seeking unique adventures. Toni is deeply committed to her community, embodying the spirit of compassion by supporting local initiatives and advocating for rescue animals. When she’s not busy promoting Downtown Melbourne as a travel hotspot, you’ll likely find her exploring new corners of the city with her rescue dachshund Allie Mae or planning her next getaway, always with the aim of discovering and sharing hidden gems. Erin Trauger DIRECTOR, 2022-PRESENT BIO Erin is President of Trauger Consulting Engineers, Inc a Melbourne-based Civil Engineering design firm.  She has nearly 20 years of local experience in Civil Engineering including due diligence, conceptual efforts, design/permitting, and construction administration of development. Erin and her husband, Jim Trauger, work together at their consulting firm located in Downtown Melbourne.  Their company project list includes commercial facilities, residential communities, industrial developments, and institutional improvements but additionally, Erin works on redevelopment projects for new updates and new life in Melbourne and other existing communities.  Erin views these redevelopment projects as wildly beneficial for developed areas and enjoys being part of the community improvements.  In the past, she served on the City of Melbourne Planning and Zoning board for six years and is excited to now be a small part of a great team that includes the Melbourne Main Street Board.  Her hopes are to serve and help further successes in an already thriving Downtown Melbourne. Jason Williams DIRECTOR, 2021-PRESENT BIO Jason Williams is the Chief Executive Officer and a Co-Founder of Cromulence LLC. Cromulence is a growing high technology business with primary offices located in Downtown Melbourne, Florida that specializes in cybersecurity capabilities and services for national defense. Jason, a Melbourne native, is inspired by the potential to vitalize and enhance the Downtown Melbourne area and attract high tech industry and technology startups. He has seen firsthand the growth of Melbourne and the Space Coast as a hub for high tech industry, aerospace, and defense and wants to see the downtown area lead as a mixed-use area for employers, restaurants, and retail businesses. Cindy Dittmer 2025-PRESENT, EX-OFFICIO BIO Kim Agee EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, 2020-PRESENT, EX-OFFICIO BIO Kim Agee is a highly skilled community and economic development strategist and the current Executive Director of Melbourne Main Street. She is an experienced connector of ideas and people and is passionate about developing relationships within the business community that achieve success. Kim is a Past Board Chair of the Melbourne Regional Chamber of Commerce and currently serves on the Board of Directors and Governance Committee, a member of CivMil, LEAD Brevard, the Junior League of South Brevard, and the City of Melbourne’s Homeless Stakeholders committee. Born and raised in Melbourne with deep family ties, Agee’s passion is her community. She loves putting her energy, dedication, and experience to work building Melbourne Main Street’s mission to strengthen the businesses in Downtown Melbourne. When she’s not working, Kim can be found boating on the Intracoastal, traveling, hugging her family and puppy, cheering on the USF Bulls, and hosting some of the best events in town. TEAM Kim Agee EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, 2020-PRESENT BIO Kim Agee is a highly skilled community and economic development strategist and the current Executive Director of Melbourne Main Street. When she’s not working, Kim can be found boating on the Intracoastal, traveling, hugging her family and puppy, cheering on the USF Bulls, and hosting some of the best events in town. Tara Weigner INTERIM MANAGER, EVENTS AND MARKETING BIO Tara Weigner has called Melbourne home for nearly six years and has a deep love for Downtown. As a former business owner in the district, she understands the importance of a thriving local community and is passionate about its continued growth. Tara is a proud mom of three and she enjoys being part of the dynamic spirit that makes Downtown Melbourne special. She looks forward to helping the area flourish and supporting the businesses that make it unique. Palm Bay football standout, 19, shot to death in Downtown Melbourne argument Search query Search the web Skip to main News Finance Sports More -1 Manage your account Help Add or switch accounts Sign out Search the web Advertisement Advertisement Return to Homepage Top Stories: Charlie Kirk fatally shot Who was Charlie Kirk? Ellison surpasses Musk Pandemic pups Trump on N.C. train stabbing Harris on Biden's decision to run Trump barred from firing Lisa Cook Trump: Epstein note a 'dead issue' 2 Americans fly to Tunisia by mistake 'Phillies Karen' viral drama Florida Today Palm Bay football standout, 19, shot to death in Downtown Melbourne argument J.D. Gallop, Florida Today Sun, May 11, 2025 at 2:31 PM UTC 2 min read MELBOURNE — A 19-year-old college football player visiting home for Mother's Day weekend was shot to death early May 11 in Downtown Melbourne following an argument outside a popular nightspot, police said. Melbourne police named the dead man as Nathaniel Bernard Jennings of Palm Bay, who played football for the University of Northwestern in Roseville, Minn. He had signed with the college last year out of Heritage High School. Nathaniel Bernard Jennings, as he appears on the University of Northwestern football roster. The suspected shooter, Stephan Dieujuste, 24, also of Palm Bay, who briefly played basketball as a point guard for Eastern Florida State College, was first questioned by detectives about the shooting after making a claim of self-defense, Melbourne police say. Dieujuste was later charged with manslaughter and taken into custody at the Brevard County Jail Complex in Sharpes. He will go before a judge Monday on a bond hearing. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement It was not known how the two men — who graduated years apart from Bayside High School and Heritage High School in Palm Bay — knew each other. Melbourne police wrap crime scene tape outside the Neon Rodeo at 829 E. New Haven Ave. in Downtown Melbourne on May 11 after a fatal shooting near the bar. The downtown area, filled with restaurants and nightclubs, was open at the time of the shooting. Police remained at the site overnight as detectives worked to sort through the statements of the shooter and other witnesses. The shooting happened about 1:51 a.m. May 11 in the area of Vernon Place and New Haven Avenue. The incident was also captured on newly installed downtown surveillance cameras several feet away, city officials said. Officers responded to the scene after receiving reports of gunfire near the recently refurbished Neon Rodeo bar and other nightspots. Officers found Jennings unresponsive. He was later pronounced dead. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement “It is an active investigation,” said Lt. Bradley Blount, a spokesperson for the Melbourne Police Department. The state attorney's office, contacted by detectives, provided guidance on the self-defense claims made in the case. The site where the shooting took place was cleared of crime scene tape later May 11. A crimson stain remained on the sidewalk where Jennings was found along the western wall of the Neon Rodeo bar. Stephan Dieujuste Police were talking with potential witnesses in the area and contacting Jennings' family in Palm Bay. It was not immediately known what caused the conflict between the two men. “It’s an unfortunate situation,” said Melbourne Mayor Paul Alfrey. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Jennings had joined nearly 10 other football players in February 2024 for National Signing Day at Heritage High, in which young athletes sign letters of intent to go to certain colleges or universities to play on the gridiron. Jennings, a defensive lineman, signed with the University of Northwestern and was listed as a freshman player. At left, Nathaniel Jennings of Heritage High School signs with the University of Northwestern to play football during National Signing Day on Feb. 7, 2024. Jennings, 19, was shot to death early on Mother's Day in downtown Melbourne, police say. The shooting is Melbourne's first reported homicide of the year. It is also the second homicide to take place in Downtown Melbourne in two years. J.D. Gallop is a criminal justice/breaking news reporter at FLORIDA TODAY. Business Ties Build Strong Downtown Melbourne - Downtown Melbourne Skip to content Home Events The Flavor Experience landing page Shop Dine Play Explore Parks Murals STAY LIVE WORK PLAN STAY LIVE WORK Directory & Map About Downtown Melbourne Melbourne Main Street Membership Leadership History News & Stories Membership Visitors Guide Contact MENU 74° Directory Events Search Home Events The Flavor Experience landing page Shop Dine Play Explore Parks Murals STAY LIVE WORK PLAN STAY LIVE WORK Directory & Map About Downtown Melbourne Melbourne Main Street Membership Leadership History News & Stories Membership Visitors Guide Contact MENU Events Directory Search × Search for: Close Home » Business Ties Build Strong Downtown Melbourne Home » About » News & Stories » Business Ties Build Strong Downtown Melbourne Business Ties Build Strong Downtown Melbourne by Kim Agee Executive Director, Melbourne Main Street November 15, 2021 Melbourne Main Street It’s no secret that Downtown Melbourne is in the midst of exciting, big changes and a new injection of energy as we emerge from the pandemic. If you live in Brevard County, how could you miss it? Pandemic aside, we were already watching Downtown transition from a protected harbor with a cozy history into a vibrant, next-generation business and entertainment hub with a youthful future. From our standpoint at Melbourne Main Street, it’s rewarding to see that journey continue in a way that does not abandon one for the other. But like most downtown areas across the country, Melbourne has much to offer while still facing great challenges. Thankfully, our downtown continues to thrive because it is loved and supported by the local community – a community that fought to not only protect local jobs and businesses early in the pandemic, but to also keep focus on the ongoing transformation that will make even our great grandchildren proud. Melbourne may date back to the late 1800’s, but Downtown was not actually designated as a distinct redevelopment area by the City of Melbourne until 1982. In 2002, it became a Main Street America™ accredited program, and part of the Florida Main Street community. The Melbourne Main Street organization, existing in its current form as a result of 17 years of board members, directors, staff, and volunteers, has been primarily focused on promoting the area’s offerings as well as laying the groundwork for growth. Having that structure and experience in place during the pandemic restrictions and now during a huge shift in consumer behavior, has been instrumental for keeping things on course. Melbourne Main Street has been, and continues to be, a trusted source of information on a number of important issues for property and business owners, as well as potential investors. Working in tandem with the downtown community to help weather economic storms, apply for grants, brainstorm marketing ideas, find new tenants, and navigate regulatory requirements are just some of the ways our organization serves. As a whole, strong connections and partnerships between Downtown Melbourne and the City of Melbourne, as well as other public entities, remain key to successful recovery and growth. We must always maintain a “seat at the table” with policy makers because what our area provides to community-wide quality of life, job availability, tax revenue, and destination tourism, is irreplaceable. Many great things are happening in Downtown. Some are related to the pandemic and a change in consumer behavior, but most are the result of years of planning and effort by the local community. Good things are yet to come. Kim Agee, Melbourne Main Street Kim Agee is a skilled community and economic development strategist and executive director of Melbourne Main Street. She drives projects and individuals to success through professional savvy and a genuine passion for the local business community. Experienced in leadership, relationship and project management, and government affairs, Kim is often the “go-to” person to activate complicated agendas and achieve organizational goals. Chumley's Depot founder dies Florida Tech downtown Melbourne legacy Prepare yourself for the opening of Brevard's first Trader Joe's. Here are some of the grocer's most popular products. News Space Sports Opinions Restaurants Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals LOCAL Chumley's Depot founder dies, leaving legacy at Florida Tech and in downtown Melbourne Rick Neale Florida Today Support local journalism. Unlock unlimited digital access to floridatoday.com Click here and subscribe today. Mike "Chumley" Gaines and Marcus Darnell met in 1995 while they were attending the Florida Institute of Technology. Both spent their college years hanging out at long-defunct Melbourne watering holes like Panther Pit, College Campus Café and Big Al's Lounge. Gaines earned a bachelor's degree in aviation management with flight. But instead of working at airports, his local legacy took flight when he founded Chumley's — Florida Tech's off-campus tavern — in 1999 at University Plaza on Babcock Street. The bar-restaurant moved to downtown Melbourne in 2014 as Chumley's Depot. Darnell, co-owner and manager, credits his friend with continuing to cultivate a judgment-free atmosphere after the move — "we don't care if the jukebox is playing Drake or Johnny Cash, as long as the music's playing.” Gaines died unexpectedly on May 10 at his Melbourne home. He was 50. His namesake bar closed for a week while its small staff grieved. More: From Mediterranean food to a speakeasy, here are 5 new restaurants to try in downtown Melbourne More: 7 Brew Coffee plans to open 165 Florida drive-thrus, with first in downtown Melbourne “I want the legacy to continue. There's no chance that I'm changing the name on that wall," Darnell said, sitting at a tavern table and gesturing toward the Chumley's Depot exterior sign. "This will be Chumley’s forever. And what he started, and what we worked together for, I will continue," Darnell said. “Twenty-five years of friendship, man. And way too many stories — we’d be here a week," he said. A celebration of life will take place from 1 to 8 p.m. June 19 at Broken Barrel Tavern in Palm Bay. Billy Chapman, The Sawgrass Band and Positive Chaos will perform, Darnell said. The original Chumley's opened its doors on June 19, 1999, at 3150 Babcock St. Two years later, Florida Tech officials opened the Clemente Center next door, directly behind the plaza. "Michael 'Chumley' Gaines was a true Florida Tech Panther who became a local business and bar owner catering to students and alumni alike," Fin Bonset, president of the Florida Tech Alumni Association, said in an email. "He was a second father, brother and family member to many of our Panther family and had a heart of gold. He helped many alumni and community members in providing a safe haven and employment opportunities at his bar/restaurant, and he always provided a shoulder to lean on simply because he was a true, genuine humanitarian who cared about everyone he ever met," Bonset said. "He will be missed as a friend, fervent community influencer, and exemplary Florida Tech alumnus," he said. More: 'I want to make my bottle proud': Message in a bottle helps Cuban singer chase American dream More: Florida Tech aviation grad to fly aboard Navy A-18G Growler during Space Coast Air Show Florida Tech Magazine featured Chumley's Depot in its fall 2019 cover story showcasing Melbourne-area alumni-owned bars. The list also included Hemingway's Tavern, Broken Barrel Tavern, Meg O'Malley's Restaurant and Irish Pub, Long Doggers and the now-defunct Lost Shirt Brewing Co. and Quarters Brewing Co. A native of Newburyport, Massachusetts, Gaines was a lifelong New England Patriots and Boston Red Sox fan — and his sports memorabilia remains on display on the tavern walls. So do images of Gaines pouring pints at Guinness Storehouse in Dublin, Ireland; standing alongside patrons and employees in a poster-sized 2013 photo from the last karaoke night at the Babcock Street location; and posing with various victorious darts league teams. Chaunette Small was introduced to Gaines through mutual friends at the bar in 2006, shortly after she moved from Gainesville to Palm Bay to pursue a master's degree in industrial organizational psychology at Florida Tech. They dated for about five years, then remained close friends afterward. She recalled one of his hobbies: writing stories that he hoped to develop into movie scripts. "He was an amazing 'Uncle Chum' that would give his extended-family nieces and nephews huge tosses into the air, and catch them and cover them with cuddles," Small said. "You could find him enjoying a lobster roll or a good game of trivia while throwing in his favorite words like 'facetious,' 'plethora,' and 'copious,' " she said. Darnell earned a bachelor's degree in aerospace engineering from Florida Tech. But like Gaines, he was destined to operate the popular off-campus tavern. “The history of Chumley's: It all came from Chumley. He was working at the Mighty Mushroom, and he told us one day, ‘Yeah, I'm just going to buy a bar,’ " Darnell recalled. "We all thought he was crazy. And then we didn't see him for like a year. And then in June of '99 after Gargoyles shut down, he bought the place and put 'Chumley's' up on the wall," he said. Darnell started working at Chumley's as a manager the following month, in July 1999. Chumley's operated at University Plaza for the next 14 years until Florida Tech officials bought the plaza and did not renew the tavern's lease, Darnell said. By that point, he said, "we were a Florida Tech bar when we started — but so many of our friends had graduated, we had become a locals bar." Chumley's moved downtown into a building near the railroad tracks on Depot Drive, between New Haven and Strawbridge avenues. Since 2000, the building had been occupied by Toy Depot, Olympia Café, Depot Café and Billy Joe's Restaurant. Darnell obtained an ownership stake in Chumley's Depot, and they spent 10 months gutting and remodeling the aging building. The tavern reopened in January 2014. "We became a successful establishment in downtown Melbourne. From a cave-like little bar in a strip mall next to Florida Tech that nobody thought would last six months," Darnell said. “We are a merry band of misfits. And if there was any bar that felt like it was home, it was this one, whether it was the old location to this location. And it's where we come and we feel safe. It's just a family. Many of our friends who are married met here,” he said. "Chumley was a large man with a larger heart. He would give you the shirt off his back." 89-year-old burlesque dancer on 'America's Got Talent': It's a yes from Cowell, Klum, Mandel, Vergara L3Harris, partner company land special operations military plane contract worth up to $3B Florida set to host two back-to-back ULA and SpaceX launches on same day this week Former Brevard County Attorney Knox violated the county's lobbying rules he signed off on Charlie Crist visits Brevard for meet-and-greet, blasts 'Rotten Ron' in campaign swing Rick Neale is the South Brevard Watchdog Reporter at FLORIDA TODAY (for more of his stories, click here .) About Melbourne Main Street | Historic Downtown Melbourne, Florida Skip to content Home Events The Flavor Experience landing page Shop Dine Play Explore Parks Murals STAY LIVE WORK PLAN STAY LIVE WORK Directory & Map About Downtown Melbourne Melbourne Main Street Membership Leadership History News & Stories Membership Visitors Guide Contact MENU 74° Directory Events Search Home Events The Flavor Experience landing page Shop Dine Play Explore Parks Murals STAY LIVE WORK PLAN STAY LIVE WORK Directory & Map About Downtown Melbourne Melbourne Main Street Membership Leadership History News & Stories Membership Visitors Guide Contact MENU Events Directory Search × Search for: Close Melbourne Main Street 2025-02-18T15:40:57-05:00 ABOUT MELBOURNE MAIN STREET A Florida Main Street Community MISSION At Melbourne Main Street, we are committed to fostering dynamic partnerships that drive the evolution of Historic Downtown Melbourne into an unparalleled hub for genuine economic activity. Our mission is to elevate and enrich the economic landscape of Historic Downtown Melbourne by amplifying and showcasing the community’s distinctive positive characteristics. Through collaborative efforts, we strive to create an environment where the unique spirit of our historic downtown thrives, attracting visitors and fostering sustainable economic growth for the benefit of our entire community. VISION At Melbourne Main Street, we envision a thriving and dynamic heart at the center of our community, where the pulse of Downtown Melbourne beats with vitality and prosperity. Our commitment as a local non-profit organization is to lead the charge in revitalizing our beloved city center, creating a destination that inspires connection, innovation, and economic growth. In our vision for Melbourne Main Street, we see a downtown that transcends its historical charm to become a modern and inclusive hub—a place where residents and visitors alike experience the rich tapestry of our community’s heritage while embracing the promise of a vibrant future. MELBOURNE MAIN STREET APPROACH Melbourne Main Street utilizes a time-tested framework for impactful, cost-effective, and community-driven revitalization for Historic Downtown Melbourne. Community transformation framework strategies and key areas of focus are outlined below: ECONOMIC VITALITY Melbourne Main Street drives the Downtown economy with tools to assist businesses, catalyze property development, and create a supportive environment for entrepreneurs and innovators. Focus Areas: Communicate the interests of the public to the City of Melbourne for support and prioritization Work with property owners to ensure a healthy and diverse Downtown Melbourne marketplace DESIGN Melbourne Main Street supports the transformation of Downtown by enhancing the physical and visual assets that set the community apart and create a safe, friendly, and inviting atmosphere. Focus Areas Façade Grant Improvement Program Beautification Projects Maintain Historical Character ORGANIZATION Melbourne Main Street creates a strong foundation for a sustainable revitalization effort, including cultivating partnerships, community involvement, and resources for Downtown. Focus Areas Board of Directors comprised of individuals with diverse talents, connections and thought Development of strategic partnerships Effective placemaking and branding Robust digital Assets PROMOTION Melbourne Main Street positions Downtown as the center of the community and hub of economic activity, while creating a positive image that showcases the community’s unique characteristics. Focus Areas Downtown Melbourne Putta Palooza Trash Bash (Part of a county wide initiative) Downtown Melbourne Botanical Fest Downtown Melbourne Flower Walk Downtown Melbourne Sidewalk Sale Downtown Melbourne Trick or Treat Downtown Melbourne Food & Wine Festival Downtown Melbourne Tree Lighting Ceremony & Candlelight Shopping MAIN STREET AMERICA – 2023 ACCREDITED As a Main Street America Accredited Main Street, Melbourne Main Street is part of a national network of more than 1,200 neighborhoods and communities that share both a commitment to creating high-quality places and to building stronger communities through preservation-based economic development. JOIN MELBOURNE MAIN STREET By partnering with Melbourne Main Street, you’re investing in the revitalization, economic vitality, visual transformation, and promotion of Historic Downtown Melbourne. History and heritage What we do Careers Contact us Left nav - about us Who we are In Melbourne, water is essential to our way of life. That’s why together with government, businesses and communities , we plan for and manage all elements of the water cycle for today, tomorrow and generations to come. From: providing clean drinking water treating sewage planning flood prevention monitoring maintaining all 25,000km of Melbourne’s rivers, creeks and catchments. Taking action in the decade that matters With increasingly unpredictable weather and more people wanting to call our region home, by 2030 nearly 6 million people will need water every day. We are in the decade that matters when the actions we take now will define our future. Our acknowledgement Through all that we do, we recognise that the Traditional Owners of the region have connections to and hold ancient knowledge of the land and water that are inseparable from their lives. In tending to all the rivers, creeks and surrounding land of our greatest backyard, we work as partners, we listen, and we tell the truth with Traditional Owners throughout our region. Our vision We are committed to enhancing life and liveability for the greater Melbourne region. Water is essential to our way of life and so is the work we do to enhance the natural environment we live in and the communities we are part of. Our values As caretakers for Melbourne’s water cycle, we care for water, life and land throughout Melbourne: both its people and its biodiversity. Our three core values are integral to the way we do that work. Make it count: We set clear expectations, prioritise fiercely and take calculated risks to achieve our goals. Dive in: We choose curiosity, lean into tough conversations and celebrate diverse perspectives. Do what’s right: We deeply care about Melbourne, our customers, and each other. We take personal responsibility for our business's performance and future The Minister for Water, in consultation with the Treasurer, appoints our Board of Directors. The victim, Nathaniel Bernard Jennings, who was attending the University of Northwestern - St. Paul, a Christian university located in Minnesota, was home in Palm Bay for summer break. He was a defensive lineman on the schools football team. FOX 35's Caroline Coles spoke with Jennings mother. The Brief Officers responded to the scene at approximately 1:51 a.m. following reports of a shooting. Upon arrival, they located a male victim who had sustained gunshot wounds. The individual was immediately transported to a local hospital, where he was later pronounced deceased. Police have one individual in custody in connection with the incident. This individual is currently claiming self-defense. BREVARD COUNTY, Fla. - A 19-year-old man is dead and another has been charged with manslaughter following a shooting early Sunday morning in downtown Melbourne, police said. 19-year-old killed in Downtown Melbourne shooting, suspect in custody, officials say A 19-year-old man is dead and another has been charged with manslaughter following a shooting early Sunday morning in downtown Melbourne, police said. Victim and suspect identified What we know: Officers responded around 1:51 a.m. to the area of Vernon Place and East New Haven Avenue after receiving reports of gunfire. Upon arrival, they found a male victim suffering from gunshot wounds. He was transported to a local hospital where he later died. The victim was identified as Nathaniel Bernard Jennings, 19, of Palm Bay. According to city officials, Jennings was visiting from out of state and had family in the area. Jennings was attending the University of Northwestern - St. Paul, a Christian university located in Minnesota. He was a defensive lineman on the schools football team. Victim - Nate Jennings | Credit: UNW athletics website Preliminary findings indicate that Jennings and the suspect were involved in a verbal altercation prior to the shooting. Melbourne police said one individual was taken into custody at the scene and initially claimed self-defense. Following further investigation, detectives identified the suspect as Stephan Dieujuste and developed probable cause for his arrest. Dieujuste was formally charged with manslaughter and booked into the Brevard County Jail Complex. Suspect - Stephan Dieujuste Authorities said the city’s surveillance camera system captured portions of the incident, aiding in the investigation. The University of Northwestern responds What they're saying: The head football coach at the University of Northwestern released a statement regarding the death of Nate Jennings: "Nate was a treasured member of our football team, being honored with all-conference accolades following his first year of collegiate competition. For as talented as Nate was on the football field, he was an even better person off of it. His contagious energy and positivity will be missed. We are praying for Nate’s mother Autumn, brother Isaiah, and other members of his extended family during this difficult time", UNW Head Football Coach Matt Moore said. Judge sets no bond What's next: On Monday, during Dieujuste's first appearance, the judge set no bond. His next court date is scheduled for June 5. Police continue to interview witnesses and urge anyone with additional information to contact the Melbourne Police Department. About the Festival and Host - DTMB Food and Wine Festival Skip to content For details on culinary exhibiting and sponsorship opportunities, please email events@downtownmelbourne .com About the Festival and Host Chris Fynan 2024-08-27T12:00:42-04:00 About the Festival The 2024 Downtown Melbourne Food and Wine Festival is set to be an exciting event on Saturday, November 9th, from 5:30 pm to 9:30 pm, presented by Sysco. The festival will feature an expanded venue along Melbourne Avenue at Crane Creek, offering double the space for attendees to enjoy a variety of food, wine, spirits, and beer. There will be live music and other entertainment, providing a vibrant atmosphere in Historic Downtown Melbourne, Florida. This year, the event is completely enclosed, ensuring that only those with valid tickets can join the fun. To ensure a smooth experience, there will be ONE designated entrance off New Haven Avenue. Parking is limited and attendees are encouraged to use rideshare services or book a stay at one of the partner hotels offering special rates. For those interested in participating as a vendor or sponsor, you can reach out via email at foodandwine@downtownmelbourne.com. Host & Charity Melbourne Main Street is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that works to build public and private partnerships to revitalize Historic Downtown Melbourne and create a 24/7 economy. An accredited Main Street, part of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, our mission is to fuel economic growth by capitalizing on the community’s assets and paying particular attention to the physical, cultural, and social identity of Downtown Melbourne. The Melbourne Main Street program was designed to enhance economic growth in the community through cultural events and social activities. We strive to promote the community identity as the “preferred destination” for quality shopping, dining, and entertainment. Come settle in for a day, an event, a weekend, or who knows? You just might feel so inclined to stick around Downtown Melbourne for good! View Directory & Map DOWNTOWN MELBOURNE – GETTING HERE Are you planning a trip to Downtown Melbourne? Find trip planning tips, instructions for getting around, transportation information, and more below. Plan your visit to Downtown Melbourne today! PARKING Free on-street parking is available along New Haven Avenue, on intersecting side streets, and on the streets around Melbourne City Hall within Downtown Melbourne. Plus, there are over 750 convenient, off-street public parking options including: City Hall Parking Garage (316 Spaces), Rosseter Lot (90 Spaces), Melbourne Avenue Lot (100 Spaces), Vernon Place Lot (45 Spaces), Hotel Melby (30 Spaces), Henegar Center (175 Spaces). BUS STOPS Are you traveling by bus? Hop on the 321 Transit (Space Coast Area Transit) and search routes serving the Downtown Melbourne area. Click here to find your route , see maps and schedules, buy bus passes, and more. PUBLIC TRANSPORT Beyond your arrival and departure from Downtown Melbourne, continuing to use a car service for the duration of your stay can be a wise and proactive way to ensure safe riding and avoid drinking and driving. Transportation via Uber, Lyft, and Taxi are some public transport options available in the Melbourne area. MELBOURNE ORLANDO INT’L AIRPORT Melbourne Orlando International Airport (MLB) is the gateway airport to Florida’s Space Coast. It is conveniently located 1.5 miles northwest (and a 10-minute drive) of Downtown Melbourne. Located in the aerospace, defense, and manufacturer neighborhood, this airport is proving primarily instrumental for those traveling to Melbourne on business, and by the same token, companies operating out of Downtown Melbourne. STAY Stay in Downtown Melbourne. Whether you’re looking for upscale, boutique hotels, or a quaint bed and breakfast, Downtown Melbourne is here to accommodate.
